dsls.markdown:
# Outbreak: Code Your Own Simulation ## Welcome to Monster Town! Monster Town was usually a happy and healthy place. The monsters of Monster town loved to wander around to visit their friends. One day, one of the monsters started feeling sick. The monster had caught a **virus**! A virus is a tiny germ that can make you sick. The other monsters were not too worried. They kept visiting their friends. Soon after, two more monsters got sick. It was the same virus! It seems they got the virus from their friend. The virus slowly spread to other monsters who were nearby. The healthy monsters began to worry that they were all going to get sick. The sick monsters began to worry that they were going to give the virus to everyone else.
## Stopping the spread Fortunately, after studying the virus, the neighbors of Monster Town made an important discovery. They realized that they were less likely to spread the virus if they wore masks over their mouths. With face masks on, sick monsters were less likely to give the virus to healthy monsters.
## What will happen next? Today, you're going to write code to create and run your own **simulation** of the virus outbreak at Monster Town. A simulation is a computer model of a process or system. Learn to code and make predictions about what will happen to the neighbors of Monster Town. * *How quickly will the virus spread?* * *Will everyone get sick?* * *How will face masks help?* When you're finished, share your simulation with others. Share your message about what you think we can do to help keep others healthy when a virus comes to town.

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Create 10 healthy sprites and 1 sick sprite. Change their size and make them wander.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions: # Creating a Simulation _Today, you're going to write code so you can run your own simulation of the virus outbreak at Monster Town._ _First, we will bring Monster Town to life by creating sprites to represent the monsters. Write your code in the_ **workspace,** _then press_ **Run** _to see your simulation. If you need any help, click the_ **lightbulb** _for a hint._ ## Do This 1. Make sprites to represent 10 healthy monsters [][0] and 1 sick monster [][1]. **Sprites** are the characters on the screen that can move, change, or interact with each other. 2. Set the size of the sprites to `50`, and make them all begin `wandering`. 3. Press `RUN`. You should see sprites moving around like the animation to the right.

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Change healthy monsters into sick monsters when they touch.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Programming with Events
_Uh oh! One of the monsters caught a virus! When a healthy monster touches a sick monster, it becomes sick too._
_To make something happen when two sprites touch, we will use this "event" block:_ [blockly block][0] _Notice that you can open this block with the blue `+` on the left side._ ## Do This Use the `subject` block inside to change **healthy monsters** [][1] into **sick monsters** [][2] when they touch.

authored_hints.hint1:
Click the `+` button on the event block. Fill the empty spot in the `change costume` block with the `subject` block found inside.

[blockly block][0]

callouts.minitoolbox: Click here to expand the block.

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Change monsters into monsters with face masks when you click them.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions: # Stopping the Outbreak with Masks _One way to slow down an outbreak is to wear a mask. Monsters with face masks will be unable to get the virus or give it to others. To make something happen when a type of monster is clicked, you can use a new type of_ "event" _block._ ## Do This 1. Use a `when clicked` block with the `change costume` block to give healthy monsters a mask when they are clicked. Repeat this for sick monsters. 2. Press `Run` and begin rapidly clicking the monsters. Try to slow or stop the outbreak by putting a mask on all the monsters.

Be sure to drag in the small red `clicked` block as well!

authored_hints.challenge:
## Looking for an extra challenge?

You can also make the monsters move faster or slower.

1.  Click `Edit` in this block [blockly block][0] 
2.  Increase or decrease the number in this block: 

[blockly block][1]

To make the monsters move slower, choose a decimal number like `0.5` or `0.25`. To make them move faster, choose any number greater than 1.

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.bubble_choice_description: Help your sprites get better automatically over time!
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: All the sick monsters now begin recovering automatically.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Recovery
_Good news: Monsters can now start to feel better on their own! Sick monsters that begin recovering will automatically change back to a healthy monster after some time passes. How do you think this will affect the outbreak?_
## Do This Run the simulation a few more times. Did anything happen differently?

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.bubble_choice_description: A virus isn't always transmitted, and masks don't stop transmission perfectly either. Improve your simulation by making infections happen with a random chance.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Add a percent chance for monsters to get sick whenever healthy monsters touch sick monsters. Do this for all combinations of monsters with and without masks.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Chance
_Right now, it's impossible for monsters to give or get the virus if either of them is wearing a mask. This sounds great, but it's not really that simple. We should add a "chance" (or probability) for the virus to spread each time any two monsters touch. We can model the chance of getting the virus off of these notes._
Notes:How face masks affect the Monster Town outbreak

_Benefits of Face Masks_ | Healthy | Sick | Chance | | :-----: | :---: | :-----------: | | [][6] | [][7] | **Very High** | | [][4] | [][5] | **High** | | [][2] | [][3] | **Low** | | [][0] | [][1] | **Very Low** |

## Do This 1. Add this **logic** block under the `when touches` event and set it to a very high chance: [blockly block][8] 2. Add more events that include monsters wearing masks and give each a different percent chance (probability). Click the lightbulb for a hint if you are not sure which events are needed. 3. Press **Finish** when you are ready to move on.

authored_hints.hint1:
You will need to add 3 more `when touches` events to check for all possible combinations of `touches` between healthy and infected sprites.

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.bubble_choice_description: Prevent your sprites from ever getting sick by giving them immunity.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Create a new costume for monsters with immunity to the virus and use it in your simulation.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Vaccines
_Vaccines can protect monsters from getting a virus. These monsters will not get sick at all!_
Next, you will create a new sprite costume to represent monsters who got a vaccine.
Learn how to modify a sprite costume. | | To modify a costume: | | ------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [expandable][0]
(Click to view) | 1. Change to the Costumes tab in the top left corner.
2. Duplicate one of the existing costumes.
3. Choose a primary color for drawing.
4. Click the Paint bucket tool, then click the monster's body to recolor it. |
Once the new costume is ready, find a way to work it into your program. For example, you can change masked monsters into vaccinated monsters when they are clicked.

authored_hints.whenclicked:

You can simulate giving monsters a vaccine when you click on them. To do this, use the `change costume` block with this event:

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Share your message!
_You can share your creation - and your message - with the world! What have you learned from this activity? What do you hope others will learn?_
The [blockly block][0] block displays text on the screen while your simulation runs. Use it to tell the user how your simulation works or to share a message. Here are some examples: [blockly block][1] [blockly block][2]

https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.short_instructions: Make any changes or improvements to your project that you would like.
https://studio.code.org/s/outbreak/lesso.long_instructions:
# Free Play
_Great job! You've been a huge help to all of the residents of Monster Town. We hope you will share what you've learned with others._
You finished the tutorial! Make any changes or improvements to your project that you would like. Press the "Share" button at the top of the page to send your project to your friends and family.
